results.title: Elijah Wood on ‘The Lord of the Rings’ at 20 and Being Frodo to Fans Forever
results.abstract: “I’ll never be upset at being associated with those films or for them being the largest in people’s memories of who I am,” the actor says.

multimedia.caption: Elijah Wood said that if he learned one thing from playing Frodo it’s “that there’s fortitude in his outlook that makes it all possible.”

results.title: ‘Nightmare Alley’ Review: Seeing Is Believing. (Suckers!)
results.abstract: Guillermo del Toro’s latest movie tracks the sordid adventures of a carnival grifter played by Bradley Cooper.

multimedia.caption: Bradley Cooper in Guillermo del Toro’s “Nightmare Alley.”

results.title: ‘Spider-Man: No Way Home’ Review: Listen Bud, No Spoilers Here
results.abstract: In the latest installment of the “Spider-Man” series, Tom Holland faces the past and a very secure franchise future.

multimedia.caption: Come fly with me: Zendaya and Tom Holland in “Spider-Man: No Way Home.”

results.title: Naples, a City of Contradictions, Is Once Again a Home for Cinema
results.abstract: For “The Hand of God,” the director Paolo Sorrentino has returned to his hometown, whose cultural profile has been lifted in recent years by the Elena Ferrante novels and films like “Gomorrah.”

multimedia.caption: The Naples seafront. The director Paolo Sorrentino has set his new film “The Hand of God” in his hometown.
multimedia.copyright: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times

results.title: ‘The Tender Bar’ Review: Where Everybody Knows His Name
results.abstract: Ben Affleck serves up whiskey and wisdom in George Clooney’s adaptation of the best-selling memoir by J.R. Moehringer.

multimedia.caption: From left, Daniel Ranieri and Ben Affleck as nephew and uncle in “The Tender Bar.”

results.title: In His Films, Big Roles Go to Passers-by and Professionals Alike
results.abstract: Sean Baker prefers a cast with a mix of experience levels. That was never more true than on “Red Rocket,” where many of the performers had never worked on a movie.

multimedia.caption: Simon Rex and Bree Elrod in Sean Baker’s newest, “Red Rocket.”

results.title: See the Real Live Man Who Grew Up in a Carnival
results.abstract: For our reporter, “Nightmare Alley” recalls a childhood spent working the circuit with his parents. Carnies like the World’s Smallest Woman welcomed him when cruel classmates didn’t.

results.title: ‘Swan Song’ Review: Second Life
results.abstract: In this future-set drama, Mahershala Ali plays an ailing father who decides whether or not to clone himself for the sake of his family.

multimedia.caption: Mahershala Ali in “Swan Song.”

results.title: Rita Moreno and Ariana DeBose: From One Anita to Another
results.abstract: The two actresses explain what the new “West Side Story” gets right, what the original lacked and why playing the role they’re both known for is so gut-wrenching.

multimedia.caption: Moreno and DeBose didn't discuss Anita’s legacy but both found inspiration in the role.
multimedia.copyright: Erik Carter for The New York Times

results.title: Kevin Feige and Amy Pascal on the Future of ‘Spider-Man’ and the M.C.U.
results.abstract: The producers of “No Way Home” address questions about another trilogy, possibly putting MJ in a Spidey suit and convincing reluctant actors to reprise their roles.

multimedia.caption: The producers Amy Pascal, left, and Kevin Feige have worked on the Spider-Man franchise in various capacities since the late 1990s.
multimedia.copyright: From left: Emma McIntyre/Getty Images; Amy Sussman/Getty Images

results.title: Streaming the Year’s Best Documentaries
results.abstract: The best movies of 2021 were even better on a big screen, The Times’s co-chief film critics wrote at year’s end. But many of their top picks are available to stream — like these five documentaries.
des_facet: Summer of Soul (... Or, When the Revolution Could Not Be Televised) (Movie)

results.title: David Arquette Spray Paints Bozo in Brooklyn
results.abstract: The “Scream” actor is on a mission to make people reconsider clowns — including himself.

multimedia.caption: “All my humor comes from me being the butt of the joke,” said Mr. Arquette, who will reprise his role in “Scream” next year.
multimedia.copyright: Sinna Nasseri for The New York Times

results.title: Five International Movies to Stream Now
results.abstract: This month’s picks include an experimental Canadian drama, an Egyptian weight-lifting documentary and a Chilean buddy comedy.

multimedia.caption: A scene from “Ste. Anne.”

results.title: How Bradley Cooper Deceives Cate Blanchett in ‘Nightmare Alley’
results.abstract: The director Guillermo del Toro narrates a sequence from his film noir.

results.title: The Most Adventurous Comedy Right Now Is Also the Most Real
results.abstract: John Wilson, Eric Andre and others are drawing on unscripted encounters to elicit deeper laughs but also more vulnerable moments.
des_facet: How To With John Wilson (TV Program)
Soft Focus with Jena Friedman (TV Program)

multimedia.caption: “How To With John Wilson” uses unscripted moments to get at complicated ideas.

results.title: ‘Rust’ Investigators Obtain Search Warrant for Alec Baldwin’s Phone
results.abstract: Detectives are nearly two months into the investigation of how a live round got into a gun that discharged on a New Mexico film set, killing a cinematographer.
results.byline: By Julia Jacobs and Graham Bowley

multimedia.caption: The set of “Rust,” where a gun the actor Alec Baldwin was practicing with fired a live round, killing the cinematographer.

results.title: ‘President’ Review: Zimbabwe’s Struggle for Democracy
results.abstract: In a riveting new documentary, Camilla Nielsson follows the first democratic election in Zimbabwe since 1980.

multimedia.caption: Nelson Chamisa, center, is the subject of the documentary “President.”

results.title: ‘Last Words’ Review: Cinema After the End of the World
results.abstract: In this post-apocalyptic drama, a young man meets the grizzled last guardian of a cinematic archive, played by Nick Nolte.

multimedia.caption: Kalipha Touray, left, and Nick Nolte in “Last Words.”

results.title: ‘Mother/Android’ Review: How to Protect When You’re Expecting
results.abstract: In this sci-fi thriller, a pregnant woman and her boyfriend try to outrun hordes of vengeful robots.

multimedia.caption: Chloë Grace Moretz, left, and Algee Smith in “Mother/Android.”

results.title: Paolo Sorrentino Turns the Camera on His Own Life
results.abstract: When he was younger, the Italian director was “skeptical” about autobiographical movies. Ten years ago, that changed, and he started work on “The Hand of God.”

multimedia.caption: Paolo Sorrentino has been making movies for 20 years, choosing subjects like Silvio Berlusconi and the pope.

results.title: ‘Fortress’ Review: Die Hard, Emote Hardly
results.abstract: A heist takes place in this thriller starring Bruce Willis, but it is audiences that might feel shortchanged.

multimedia.caption: Bruce Willis in “Fortress.”

results.title: ‘The Novice’ Review: A Freshman Effort Worthy of Varsity
results.abstract: The obsessive ambitions of a college rower are masterfully orchestrated in a debut feature by the writer-director Lauren Hadaway.

multimedia.caption: Isabelle Fuhrman as the rower Alex Dall in “The Novice.”

results.title: ‘A Naija Christmas’ Review: Honoring a Mother’s Wish
results.abstract: In this romantic comedy on Netflix, the first son to find a wife inherits the family home. But that task is harder than it might appear.

multimedia.caption: Abayomi Alvin, Rachel Oniga and Kunle Remi in “A Naija Christmas.”

results.title: ‘The Scary of Sixty-First’ Review: Resident Evil
results.abstract: A Manhattan apartment turns into the rental from hell in this mindless mix of horror and true crime.

multimedia.caption: Dasha Nekrasova in “The Scary of Sixty-First.”

results.title: ‘Juice WRLD: Into the Abyss’ Review: Free Fall
results.abstract: This unfocused documentary looks at the career of the rapper Juice WRLD, who died of an accidental overdose in 2019.

multimedia.caption: The rapper Juice WRLD is the subject of the documentary “Juice WRLD: Into the Abyss.”

results.title: The Breakout Stars of 2021
results.abstract: In a year that offered glimmers of hope across the world of arts, these performers and creators rose to the occasion.

multimedia.caption: Olivia Rodrigo, members of the cast of “Reservation Dogs” and a scene from “Sanctuary City.”
multimedia.copyright: Clockwise from left: Mat Hayward/Getty Images; jeremy Dennis for The New York Times; Sara Krulwich/The New York Times

results.title: ‘My Girlfriend’s Wedding’: Her Life Plays Like a Movie
results.abstract: Newly restored, Jim McBride’s 1969 documentary is about his lover who gets married to another man. Her story remains anything but boring.

multimedia.caption: Clarissa Dalrymple and Jim McBride in his 1969 documentary.’s Wedding.”

results.title: Forget Naturalism. With Movie Acting This Year, Big Swings Are In.
results.abstract: Aim-for-the-fences performances from Lady Gaga, Ben Affleck and many others are making waves, and we’re here for the outrageous fun.

multimedia.caption: Lady Gaga pouring it on in “House of Gucci.”

results.title: Let’s Look Back on 2021, When We Couldn’t Stop Looking Back
results.abstract: There’s now a thriving cottage industry for content that re-examines the recent past through a contemporary critical lens. Is that a good thing?

multimedia.caption: The documentary “Woodstock 99: Peace, Love, and Rage” argues that 1999 was a very particular time in pop culture, seemingly alien to anyone who didn’t live through it.

results.title: I Watched ‘Encanto’ With My Dad. It Brought Him Back Home.
results.abstract: The animated Disney movie is set in Colombia, where my father is from — a place he rarely talks about. Would he fall for the film?

multimedia.caption: In the animated movie “Encanto,” which is set in Colombia, Mirabel Madrigal (Stephanie Beatriz) is the only child in the family without a fantastical gift.

results.title: ‘Rumble’ Review: He’s Not Ready, but His Coach Is Very Persuasive
results.abstract: Steve is being pressed into service as a wrestler in training, but if he had a choice he’d prefer a rumba to a rumble.

multimedia.caption: Steve (voiced by Will Arnett), the not highly motivated wrestler but passionate salsa dancer, and his coach, Winnie (voiced by Geraldine Viswanathan).

results.title: ‘The Hand of God’ Review: A Portrait of the Cineaste as a Young Man
results.abstract: Paolo Sorrentino’s autobiographical drama about growing up in Naples is sensual, sad and occasionally sublime.

multimedia.caption: A scene from Paolo Sorrentino's "The Hand of God," which keeps company with recent memoir-like movies.

results.title: ‘The Royal Tenenbaums’ at 20: When Wes Anderson Imagined New York
results.abstract: The film’s vision of the city is at once entirely made up and very real seeming, both dated and contemporary. But the movie couldn’t outrun current events.

multimedia.caption: Gene Hackman, left, Luke Wilson, Gwyneth Paltrow and Danny Glover in “The Royal Tenenbaums.”
